item.title: Japan’s New Prime Minister Set to Call Snap Election
item.description: Sanae Takaichi hopes to cement her grip on power as she battles Chinese anger over remarks she made about Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Jason Douglas

item.title: China Imports to Help Lower U.K. Inflation to Target, BOE’s Taylor Says
item.description: The annual rate of inflation is likely to fall to the Bank of England’s 2% target by the middle of this year, aided by cheap imports from China, the rate-setter said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: China’s Trade Surplus Reaches Record, Defying Expectations of Tariff-Driven Slowdown
item.description: China posted a record trade surplus for 2025, as fresh data showed the world’s second-largest economy remained resilient despite facing steep tariffs from the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miao

item.title: Venezuela Frees Detained Americans in Slow Release of Political Prisoners
item.description: U.S. officials described the move as an important step in the wake of the authoritarian leader Nicolás Maduro’s ouster.
item.dc:creator: Michael Amon

item.title: Venezuelan Opposition’s Calls to Oust Maduro Aided Legal Case for Removal, Memo Says
item.description: The assertion that helped justify the U.S. military operation against the Venezuelan leader was redacted in a publicly released version of the Justice Department memo.
item.dc:creator: Vera Bergengruen

item.title: U.S. to Unveil Gaza Governance Plan Despite Concerns Over Hamas
item.description: Hamas hasn’t yet begun disarming, a fact some officials believe could imperil the peace plan.
item.dc:creator: Anat Peled

item.title: The Obscure Bank Collapse That Sent Iran Into a Tailspin
item.description: Bad loans to regime cronies brought down Ayandeh Bank, accelerating a long-running financial crisis.
item.dc:creator: Jared Malsin

item.title: U.S. Blows Up China’s Latin America Ambitions With Maduro Ouster
item.description: Beijing is recalculating its policy of making inroads in Washington’s backyard after its top ally there was deposed.
item.dc:creator: Lingling Wei

item.title: The U.S.’s Two Foremost Asian Allies Are on Good Terms—an Irritant for China
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung and Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi displayed unity in a high-profile summit.
item.dc:creator: Jason Douglas

item.title: Opinion | What Does the U.S. Operation in Venezuela Mean?
item.description: University students react to the capture of Nicolás Maduro and discuss what it means for them and for the world.

item.title: Trump Tells Iranian Protesters ‘Help Is On Its Way’
item.description: The president rules out talks with Iran’s regime after the deaths of hundreds of demonstrators, and says Americans should leave the country.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Faucon

item.title: An Isolated Iran Finds China’s Friendship Has Limits
item.description: Beijing denounced Trump’s 25% tariff on countries that do business with Tehran, but seems reluctant to offer more support.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy

item.title: Opinion | DNC Chair Ken Martin on Iran and ICE
item.description: The head of the Democratic Party looks at the Tehran regime and sees Trump’s America.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Iran’s Gulf Rivals Warn U.S. Against Strike on Tehran
item.description: Saudi Arabia is leading the charge to persuade Washington not to intervene.
item.dc:creator: Omar Abdel-Baqui

item.title: Greenland’s Prime Minister Says Island Would Choose Denmark Over U.S.
item.description: The Arctic island’s leader seeks to portray unity with Copenhagen ahead of White House meetings on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Sune Engel Rasmussen

item.title: Iran Is Hunting Down Starlink Users to Stop Protest Videos From Going Global
item.description: Video from the streets is one of the few ways of getting information out about the scale of the protests and the actions of Iranian authorities.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Faucon

item.title: Opinion | What Venezuela Should Remember From Iraq
item.description: Recovery will require reliable economic arrangements.

item.title: Opinion | Greenland or NATO? Trump Can’t Have Both
item.description: It isn’t for sale, and the consequences of a military takeover would be dire.
item.dc:creator: William A. Galston

item.title: South Korean Prosecutors Seek Death Penalty for Former Leader
item.description: Judges will review the recommendation for Yoon Suk Yeol, who briefly instituted martial law over a year ago and faced charges of insurrection.
item.dc:creator: Dasl Yoon

item.title: The Battle Over Who Runs the Panama Canal Ports Is About to Be Decided
item.description: The Panamanian Supreme Court is winding up deliberations in a lawsuit that could void a Chinese company’s license to operate the ports and hand President Trump a win.
item.dc:creator: Santiago Pérez

item.title: U.K. House Prices Expected to Rise But London Likely to Straggle
item.description: U.K. house prices are expected to rise in 2026, with Scotland and Northern England showing the strongest growth and sales prospects, according to real-estate website Zoopla.
item.dc:creator: Anthony O. Goriainoff

item.title: Japan Stock Index Hits New Record on Hopes for General Election
item.description: Expectations are growing for a general election next month that could solidify Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi’s political standing and allow her to take bolder steps to boost the economy.
item.dc:creator: Kosaku Narioka

item.title: Military Experts Reject Trump’s Logic That U.S. Must Own Greenland to Defend It
item.description: The president’s assertion runs counter to decades of policy and undermines deterrence, say former military and diplomatic officials.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Michaels

item.title: A Custody Battle Over Dogs Rocks an African Nation
item.description: Palace guard dogs are said to protect Malawi’s president from intruders and witchcraft. The outgoing leader decided to keep a few.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: White House Weighs Iran’s Nuclear-Talks Offer as Trump Leans Toward Strikes
item.description: Some senior administration aides, led by Vice President JD Vance, are urging Trump to try diplomacy before retaliating against Iran for killing protesters.

item.title: Canada Anticipates Progress in China Talks to Resolve Trade Row
item.description: Canada anticipates progress with China on resolving trade irritants regarding canola and electric vehicles during Prime Minister Mark Carney visit’s to Beijing this week, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: U.S. Tries a New Playbook: Regime Management, Not Regime Change
item.description: After costly failures in Iraq and Afghanistan, the Trump administration is betting that managing Venezuela’s autocracy is cheaper than dismantling it.
item.dc:creator: David Luhnow

item.title: ECB’s Villeroy Backs Powell, Sees 2026 Rate Rise as ‘Fanciful’
item.description: The ECB is very unlikely to raise its key interest rate this year, with a weaker dollar among a number of potential developments keeping eurozone inflation low, Bank of France Governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Weakened by War, Iran’s Regime Faces Its Toughest Challenge Yet
item.description: Iranian leaders’ last claim to legitimacy was shattered in the war with Israel.

item.title: Australia’s Critical Minerals Reserve to First Focus on Antimony, Gallium, Rare Earths

item.title: Inside Ukraine’s Quest to Build a Missile to Strike Deep in Russian Territory

item.title: Iran Toughens Crackdown, as U.S. Sketches Out Military Options
item.description: Iranian authorities stepped up warnings against protesters as the death toll mounted and U.S. authorities discussed how to carry out Trump’s threat to intervene.

item.title: Greenland Was America’s Friend. Now It’s a Takeover Target.
item.description: Few locals in Nuuk believe U.S. troops are arriving imminently, but there is growing unease that President Trump’s desire to buy Greenland or use military force might actually be serious.

item.description: The deal aims to blunt the impact of U.S. tariffs and curb Europe’s economic dependence on China.

item.title: China Warns AI Startups Seeking to Emulate Meta Deal: Not So Fast
item.description: Beijing worries the $2.5 billion acquisition of startup Manus will encourage more entrepreneurs to follow in its footsteps.

item.title: China Detains Church Leaders as Crackdown on Religion Intensifies
item.description: Authorities have taken away at least four members of a high-profile “house church” in Sichuan province as a campaign to root out religious organizations beyond the state’s control intensifies.

item.title: China’s Forex Reserves Rose in December as Yuan Debate Mounts
item.description: China’s foreign-exchange reserves rose in December amid a weaker dollar, wrapping up a year marked by a ballooning trade surplus.

item.description: Audrey Truschke’s single-volume work makes a bold attempt to capture thousands of years of cultural ferment on the Indian subcontinent.
